perturbation.original_text: Without limiting any other provision of this Section 6.3, if at any time Newegg reasonably determines that Allied’s use of the Newegg Marks fails to comply with this Agreement or to conform to the Acceptable Quality Standards, Allied shall, within five (5) days of receipt of notice from Newegg, correct its use of the Newegg Marks so that its use is in compliance with this Agreement and the Acceptable Quality Standards or cease using, and remove, the Newegg Marks from all of Allied’s videos, streams and other publications in all media (“Allied’s Correction Action”).
perturbation.changed_text: Without limiting any other provision of this Section 6.3, if at any time Newegg reasonably determines that Allied’s use of the Newegg Marks fails to comply with this Agreement or to conform to the Acceptable Quality Standards, Allied shall, within one (1) day of receipt of notice from Newegg, correct its use of the Newegg Marks so that its use is in compliance with this Agreement and the Acceptable Quality Standards or cease using, and remove, the Newegg Marks from all of Allied’s videos, streams and other publications in all media (“Allied’s Correction Action”).
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides Allied with five days to correct its use of Newegg Marks. Decreasing this cure period to one day is unreasonable and potentially conflicts with general contract law principles, which typically allow a reasonable timeframe for curing breaches, especially given the scope of potential corrective actions (removing marks from 'all of Allied’s videos, streams and other publications in all media'). California law generally requires a 'reasonable time' for cure, and one day might be deemed insufficient depending on the circumstances.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Contract Law - implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, requiring a 'reasonable time' for cure.

perturbation.original_text: Before any Party (the “Complaining Party”) may bring any legal proceeding against the other (the “Non Complaining Party”), the Complaining Party shall first make a reasonable and good faith attempt to resolve all disputes privately by notifying and providing to the Non Complaining Party of the Complaining Party’s complaints, reasons and supporting evidence for the complaints, and the reasonable steps Complaining Party would like the Non Complaining Party to take in order to address the complaints. If for any reason the Non-Complaining Party disagrees with either the complaint or the steps suggested to address the complaints, the Parties shall discuss and work on an amicable solution for at least thirty (30) days before the Complaining Party may bring any legal proceeding to resolve the complaints.
perturbation.changed_text: Before any Party (the “Complaining Party”) may bring any legal proceeding against the other (the “Non Complaining Party”), the Complaining Party shall first make a reasonable and good faith attempt to resolve all disputes privately by notifying and providing to the Non Complaining Party of the Complaining Party’s complaints, reasons and supporting evidence for the complaints, and the reasonable steps Complaining Party would like the Non Complaining Party to take in order to address the complaints. If for any reason the Non-Complaining Party disagrees with either the complaint or the steps suggested to address the complaints, the Parties shall discuss and work on an amicable solution for at least ten (10) days before the Complaining Party may bring any legal proceeding to resolve the complaints.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates a 30-day period for amicable resolution before legal proceedings can commence. Reducing this period to 10 days could be deemed insufficient, particularly for complex disputes, and thus conflict with California's requirements for meaningful pre-litigation dispute resolution. Many California courts encourage longer periods for mediation or settlement discussions, especially in commercial disputes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Code of Civil Procedure Section 1281, et seq. - principles of arbitration and mediation encouraging meaningful dispute resolution efforts.

perturbation.original_text: Failure by Allied to perform and comply with any of its obligations in sections 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12 and 13 of this Agreement shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement and Newegg shall have the right to terminate this Agreement immediately if Allied fails to cure the breach within fifteen (15) days following Newegg’s written notice of the breach.
perturbation.changed_text: Failure by Allied to perform and comply with any of its obligations in sections 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12 and 13 of this Agreement shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement and Newegg shall have the right to terminate this Agreement immediately if Allied fails to cure the breach within two (2) days following Newegg’s written notice of the breach.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for material breaches from fifteen days to two days creates an unreasonably short timeframe for Allied to rectify any failures. Under California law, the breaching party is generally entitled to a reasonable opportunity to cure the breach, and a two-day period might be considered insufficient and therefore unenforceable, particularly if the breach involves complex operational or financial issues.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Civil Code Section 1442 - requirement of reasonable time to cure breach.
